citation.article-title: Serratia entomophila sp. nov. associated with amber disease in the New Zealand grass grub Costelytra zealandica.

p.s: Description of Serratia entomophila sp. nov.
Serratia entomophila (en.to.mo'phi.la. Gr. noun entomon, insect; Gr. vb. phylein, love; L. fem. adj. entomophila, insect loving)
Cells are gram-negative , nonsporeforming, nonencapsulated , straight rods with peritrichous flagella.
The species conforms to the definition of the family Enterobacteriaceae (4) and produces the enterobacterial common antigen.
All strains grow on nutrient agar, producing colonies of about 2.5 to 3 mm in diameter after 24 h at 30 or 37°C.
The colonies are whitish and opaque and have smooth, entire edges.
Facultatively anaerobic.
All strains grow well in 1 day at 10, 20, 30, and 37°C and weakly at 4°C (in 4 days) or 41°C (in 1 day) in tryptic soy broth.
However, 37°C is not optimal for biochemical characterization, and incubation at 30°C is preferred.
No growth occurs at or above 42°C.
Growth occurs on caprylate-thallous agar at 30°C in 2 to 6 days.
Catalase produced.
Oxidase not produced.
Nitrates reduced to nitrites.
Tetrathionate not reduced.
H2S not produced in glucose-lactose-iron agar or triple sugar iron agar.
Urea not hydrolyzed in urea-indole medium. o-Nitrophenyl-β-D-galactopyranoside hydrolyzed.
γ-Glutamyltransferase test positive; β-glucuronidase and β-xylosidase tests negative.
Indole not produced in peptone water or urea-indole medium.
Tryptophan and phenylalanine not deaminated.
Lysine, arginine, and ornithine not decarboxylated (Mgller medium).
Tributyrin and chitin hydrolyzed by most strains; DNA, gelatin, Tween 20, Tween 40, Tween 60, and Tween 80 hydrolyzed.
Starch not hydrolyzed in 4 days.
Glucose fermented without gas production.
Voges-Proskauer test positive.
Methyl red usually negative.

Acid produced from adonitol (2 to 4 days), D-cellobiose (3 to 4 days), galacturonate (1 to 4 days), glycerol (1 to 4 days), myo-inositol (1 to 4 days), maltose (1 day), D-mannitol (1 day), D-mannose (1 day), salicin (1 day), sucrose (1 day), and trehalose (1 day).
Acid production from D-arabitol and D-xylose defines biotypes.
No acid produced from L-arabinose, dulcitol, lactose, melibiose, α-methyl-D-glucoside, D-raffinose, L-rhamnose, D-sorbitol, and L-sorbose.
Esculin hydrolyzed, Gluconate test positive.
Growth on Simmons citrate.
No growth factor required.
Malonate test negative.

The following compounds are utilized as sole carbon and energy sources by all strains (in 1 to 4 days): N-acetyl-D-glucosamine, cis-aconitate, trans-aconitate, adonitol, D-alanine, L-alanine, L-aspartate, D-cellobiose, citrate, β-D-fructose, α-L-fucose, fumarate, D-galactose, D-galacturonate, β-gentiobiose, D-gluconate, D-glucosamine , D-glucose , D-glucuronate, L-glutamate, DL-glycerate, glycerol, L-histidine, myo-inositol, itaconate, 2-keto-D-gluconate, 5-keto-D-gluconate, DL-lactate, L-malate, maltose, maltotriose, D-mannitol, D-mannose, β-methyl-D-glucoside, L-proline, putrescine, D-ribose, salicin, L-serine, succinate, sucrose, and D-trehalose.
Utilization of D-arabitol, L-arabitol, and D-xylose define two biotypes.
Most strains utilize benzoate, caprate, phenylacetate, propionate, quinate, and L-tyrosine.

The following compounds are not utilized as sole carbon and energy sources: β-alanine, DL-Yamino-n-valerate, L-arabinose, betaine, o-coumarate, 2-deoxy- D-glucose, 2,3-dihydroxybenzoate, 2,4-dihydroxybenzoate, 3,5-dihydroxybenzoate, dulcitol, meso-erythritol, ethanolamine, ferulate, gentisate, glycine, heptanoate, histamine, 3-hydroxybenzoate, 4-hydroxybenzoate, DL-β-hydroxybutyrate, lactose, lactulose, malonate, maltitol, D-melezitose, D-melibiose, L-methionine, methyl-α-galactoside, methyl-β-galactoside, 3-O-methylglucose, α-methyl-D-glucoside, methyl-α-D-mannoside, α-methyl-D-xyloside, mucate, palatinose, 3-phenylpropionate, protocatechuate, D-raffinose, L-rhamnose, saccharate, sarcosine, D-sorbitol, L-sorbose, D-tagatose, D-tartrate, L-tartrate, meso-tartrate, tricarballylate, trigonelline, tryptamine, D-tryptophan, D-turanose, and vanilate.
Most strains failed to utilize glutarate, D-malate, and xylitol.
The G+C content of the DNA is 58 mol%.
Isolated from larvae of C. zealandica (grass grub) with amber disease, and from the environment.
No strain has been identified as being involved in a human, animal (other than insect), or plant disease.
The type strain is strain A1T (ATCC 43705T).
Strain A1T has all the characteristics given above for the species.
In addition, this strain failed to utilize benzoate, caprate, aketoglutarate, phenylacetate, or propionate as the sole source of carbon and energy.
Experimentally (per os) pathogenic for C. zealandica larvae.
